title: How to Keep Your Grass Green in the Winter

steps.headline: Rake and get rid of fallen leaves in preparation of seeding.
steps.description: Tree leaves can prevent light from accessing your grass and stop seeds from hitting the soil. Additionally, raking will stir surface soil which is a useful way to support the roots of your grass. Clearing your lawn is also going to help with weeding and mowing.

steps.headline: Remove weeds to avoid your grass getting killed.
steps.description: Weeds are relentless in their pursuit to grow so take them out as soon as you can. If you don’t then they’ll target your lawns and deprive your grass of nutrients. The damage will be worse in the winter time if it isn’t tended to.

steps.headline: Mow grass at a height that is slightly higher than normal.
steps.description: Raising your mowing height will concurrently give your grass deeper roots. Not only that but it will also insulate it. Don’t leave it too long though because in winter the grass can become matted. About two thirds of your cutting height in opposition of the general half should do the trick.

steps.headline: Begin overseeding as early as autumn.
steps.description: No matter which hemisphere you’re stationed on, this is a period when conditions are ripe for germination due to cool air temperature and warm soil. Overseeding will allow more chances for the grass to grow without any negative ramifications. This also grants the seedlings plenty of time to develop. For best results, use a seed spreader. If you don’t own one you can rent one for the day at your local gardening shop. There are different species of seeds for different circumstances. Perennial Ryegrass is standard. Fine Fescue is for shaded areas. Tall Fescue is for areas susceptible to droughts.

steps.headline: Water your seedlings every day for up to 3 times a day.
steps.description: Germination can happen as early as 7 days into the process, but can sometimes take as long as 21. Stop watering the grass once it grows to one inch tall. After which you’ll only have to water the grass once a day.

steps.headline: Fertilize the grass early to provide nutrients for the winter.
steps.description: Do this a little bit before the winter season comes around in order to feed the roots. If you live in a country that snows, it’ll strengthen the condition of your grass when the frost hits. If you don’t fertilize before the winter it will be too late. There are special winter fertilizers that are specifically designed for this exact scenario. Check with your local gardening shop to see what they have available.

parts.name: Taking Care of Your Grass During Winter

steps.headline: Refrain from mowing grass after it has rained.
steps.description: When it gets moist in the winter time, mowing will do more harm than good, especially if it has been snowing. Using a lawnmower on wet grass will damage the roots and can even kill it.

steps.headline: Restrict the amount of walking on your lawn to keep the grass healthy.
steps.description: Staying off the grass will give it a better opportunity to grow, especially in winter. Trampling over it in wet and cold conditions will severely reduce its survival rate so your grass should be treated tenderly.

steps.headline: Keep your lawn clear of objects and outdoor furniture.
steps.description: Leave heavy belongings such as lawn-chairs and children’s toys off the grass to prevent getting dead spots. Putting weight on grass that is already fragile due to winter conditions will turn it brown. Not only that, when spring time comes back around those particular dead spots won’t flourish. The dead grass attained by heavy objects can even cause it to become diseased which will lure in pests such as mice and insects.

steps.headline: Consider chipping away ice to give your grass more of a fighting chance.
steps.description: Your lawns can endure a lot of harsh weather conditions, especially if you’ve implemented the preliminary nurturing techniques in autumn, but manually removing deep shards of ice can help strengthen your lawn against the elements.
